{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3635480,"name":"Prince","username":"Prince","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/ba9def/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-25T15:42:08.577Z","cooked":"

This is our first year doing full field localization. We have the overall system running but we are having trouble keeping the pose accurate. The final goal of the system is to be able have auto align to all position on the reef. We were planning on using the pathplanner whitepaper written by spartronics to implement drive to pose. How do we tune things like std devs? And is there any other methods of tuning. Currently we do little to no filtering. We just feed in the vision values into the swerve drive pose estimator. How has everyone else gone about doing this?

Here is our current code: https://github.com/OCHS-STEM-Club/2025-CompBot-YAGSL

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-05-25T15:43:50.718Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":20,"reads":222,"readers_count":221,"score":159.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502370,"topic_slug":"global-pose-estimation","display_username":"Prince","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/OCHS-STEM-Club/2025-CompBot-YAGSL","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - OCHS-STEM-Club/2025-CompBot-YAGSL","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57204,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1792 Lead Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/global-pose-estimation/502370/1","custom_user_title":"1792 Lead Programmer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3635486,"name":"Jade","username":"spacey_sooty","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/spacey_sooty/{size}/256378_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-25T15:58:56.233Z","cooked":"

There are two major things you’ve covered here, data filtering and tuning your stddevs.

For data filtering I’d recommend looking at what the AdvantageKit vision template does as a good starting point. The idea is we can use certain values we know to be within a certain range to reject values that are erroneous.

Your stddevs are a statistical representation of how accurate your positions are. You can see the units of them in the documentation. Essentially as your stddevs go up you give less trust to your measurements and vice versa with 0 assuming your measurements are a ground truth (which they never are so your stddevs should never be zero). The higher your stddevs are the more stable your measurements will be (as each measurement is able to be smoothed better) at the sacrifice of accuracy. You should aim to keep your stddevs as low as possible while keeping your pose stable when tuning. There are a lot of different ways to tune these and I’d advise doing some more research into different methods but the AdvantageKit template provides a simple approach based off information from each detection you can see here which should reduce how much tuning you need to do.

Note there are a lot of factors that contribute to accuracy outside of this. Things like the quality of your camera calibration and motion tearing have a major impact on pose accuracy and you should use telemetry data to identify where the innacuracy in your system is coming from.

Barker","username":"therekrab","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therekrab/{size}/248500_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-25T15:59:42.651Z","cooked":"

Our team had full field localization last year, but this year we learned a lot more about how to tune it to be an accurate system. Here’s our biggest takeaways:

Filtering bad results

We filter a lot of our results to make sure that we only accept good data. There are a couple simple checks on latency and ambiguity that we use to decide if an estimate is even worth continuing to process, but after that it gets a little more complex.

We also filter out any results that would have the robot outside the field.

When the robot is disabled, we also filter out any results that are “impossible”. This is possible because we have multiple cameras. If one pose estimate would have the robot in a position on the field where another camera wouldn’t be able to see the tags that it currently does, that pose estimate is guaranteed wrong. This only runs when the robot is disabled, however, because it is somewhat intensive on the RoboRIO and we see loop times increase on the vision thread when we run this. Not a problem for a stationary robot, but it’s a big issue when we’re on the move.

Weighing results

Like you mentioned, tuning the standard deviations matrix that is associated with vision updates is critical to tuning vision updates. For a quick recap of what we did, we used data about each pose estimate to dynamically change that matrix so that the good results got trusted a lot, and the bad results were not weighted as highly. I already wrote a post about this, which outlines more specifically how we did this.

I hope this helps.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-05-25T15:59:42.651Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":153,"readers_count":152,"score":50.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":502370,"topic_slug":"global-pose-estimation","display_username":"Nolan Barker","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/localization-finding-standard-deviations-for-setvisionmeasurementstddevs/496596/7","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Localization: Finding Standard Deviations for SetVisionMeasurementStdDevs","clicks":7}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65568,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming Lead, Co-captain | 3414 Hackbots"},"post_url":"/t/global-pose-estimation/502370/3","custom_user_title":"Programming Lead, Co-captain | 3414 Hackbots","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3635513,"name":"Mete Karadeniz","username":"irresistiable","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/f19dbf/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-25T16:30:05.906Z","cooked":"

You’re definitely on the right path. From our experience, the two biggest things that improved pose accuracy were proper filtering and tuning stddevs.

Raw vision data without filtering can easily throw off your pose. AdvantageKit’s vision template is a great reference they reject data with high ambiguity, bad latency, or positions off the field. Adding even simple checks like those made a big difference for us.

For stddevs, think of them as how much you trust the vision. Lower = more trust, higher = less. But they should never be zero. Tuning them right means finding the balance between trusting good data and ignoring bad data. Some teams adjust stddevs dynamically based on tag quality AdvantageKit does this too and it’s a solid starting point.

Also, don’t overlook camera calibration and motion blur they matter more than you’d think. Using telemetry to see where your errors come from helps a ton.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-05-25T16:30:05.906Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":128,"readers_count":127,"score":30.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":502370,"topic_slug":"global-pose-estimation","display_username":"Mete Karadeniz","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68396,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/global-pose-estimation/502370/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3635534,"name":"Muaz","username":"mtareen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mtareen/{size}/268933_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-25T17:20:55.136Z","cooked":"

I don’t know if you guys are already doing this right now, but one thing that helps us a ton is not using just the vision estimates but pairing them with odometry as well. We do this with WPILib’s SwervePoseEstimator (i think this is what it’s called). Fusing the odometry and vision estimates into one pose really helps with overall accuracy, as odometry can be pretty accurate as long as you’re updating with vision to mitigate bad data from wheel slippage. It also helps when you can’t see a tag for some reason, you’ll still have your odometry to go off of.
